To enhance information freshness while saving energy, we formulate a joint optimization problem to minimize the weighted sum of average age of information (AoI) and total energy consumption by jointly optimizing task offloading decisions, resource allocation, and AIRS configuration including its deployment position, phase shifts, and panel size, subject to offloading quality and computing deadline constraints. To tackle the resulting mixed-integer and nonconvex problem, we develop a hierarchical optimization framework based on the objective priority and variable coupling relations. Under this framework, the problem is solved in two stages using quadratic penalty, numerical analysis, and convex optimization techniques. Specifically, an AoI-aware task offloading policy is first designed to maximize information freshness; subsequently, given the obtained offloading policy, an AIRS configuration and resource allocation scheme is proposed to minimize energy consumption. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms benchmark schemes in reducing both AoI and energy consumption, while exhibiting superior convergence performance.

title: High-Fidelity Seismic Super-Resolution Using Prior-Informed Deep Learning with 3D Awareness
authors: Jintao Li, Xinming Wu, Xianwen Zhang, Xin Du, Xiaoming Sun, Bao Deng, Guangyu Wang
abstract: The limitations of seismic vertical resolution pose significant challenges for the identification of thin beds. Improving the vertical resolution of seismic data using deep learning methods often encounters challenges related to unrealistic outputs and limited generalization. To address these challenges, we propose a novel framework that improves the fidelity and generalization of seismic super-resolution. Our approach begins with the generation of realistic synthetic training data that aligns with the structural and amplitude characteristics of field surveys. We then introduce an enhanced 2D network with 3D awareness, which builds on the 2D Swin-Transformer and 3D convolution blocks to effectively capture 3D spatial features while maintaining computational efficiency. This network addresses the limitations of traditional 2D approaches by reducing stitching artifacts and improving spatial consistency. Finally, we develop a prior-informed fine-tuning strategy using field data without the need for labels, which incorporates a self-supervised data consistency loss and a spectral matching loss based on prior knowledge. This strategy ensures that the super-resolution results preserve the original low frequency information while yielding a spectral distribution as expected. Experiments on multiple field datasets demonstrate the robustness and generalization capability of our method, making it a practical solution for seismic resolution enhancement in diverse field datasets.

authors: N/A

title: Study on Scalable Model of Multifinger Structure for GaN p-i-n Diode
authors: Jiawei Li, Xuanwu Kang, Hengyu Shang, Hao Wu, Yingkui Zheng, Wenjing Jiang, Rikang Zhao, Peihao Xu, Ke Wei, Xinyu Liu
abstract: This article proposes a parameter extraction method for gallium nitride (GaN) p-i-n diodes and studies the scalability of device parameter models in microwave circuit design. Established scaling rules for intrinsic model parameters between diodes with varying effective junction areas and different numbers of fingers. The performance of large-sized and multifinger devices can be accurately predicted using these scalable models. Under both cutoff and conduction bias conditions, the S-parameters of the GaN p-i-n diode model exhibit excellent agreement with measured results across the frequency range of 0.1–40GHz.

title: FreeSplat++: Generalizable 3D Gaussian Splatting for Efficient Indoor Scene Reconstruction_supp1-3665771.mp4
authors: Gim Hee Lee
abstract: Recently, the integration of the efficient feed-forward scheme into 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has been actively explored. However, most existing methods focus on sparse view reconstruction of small regions and cannot produce eligible whole-scene reconstruction results in terms of either quality or efficiency. In this paper, we propose FreeSplat++, which focuses on extending the generalizable 3DGS to become an alternative approach to large-scale indoor whole-scene reconstruction, which has the potential of significantly accelerating the reconstruction speed and improving the geometric accuracy. To facilitate whole-scene reconstruction, we initially propose the Low-cost Cross-View Aggregation framework to efficiently process extremely long input sequences. Subsequently, we introduce a carefully designed pixel-wise triplet fusion method to incrementally aggregate the overlapping 3D Gaussian primitives from multiple views, adaptively reducing their redundancy. Furthermore, given the fused 3DGS primitives with accumulated weights after the fusion step, we propose a weighted floater removal strategy that can effectively reduce floaters, which serves as an explicit depth fusion approach that is tailored for generalizable 3DGS methods and becomes crucial in whole-scene reconstruction. After the feed-forward reconstruction of 3DGS primitives, we investigate a depth-regularized per-scene fine-tuning process. Leveraging the dense, multi-view consistent depth maps obtained during the feed-forward prediction phase for an extra constraint, we refine the entire scene's 3DGS primitive to enhance rendering quality while preserving geometric accuracy. Extensive experiments confirm that our FreeSplat++ significantly outperforms existing generalizable 3DGS methods, especially in whole scene reconstructions. Compared to conventional per-scene optimized 3DGS approaches, our method with depth-regularized per-scene fine-tuning demonstrates substantial improvements in reconstruction accuracy and a notable reduction in training time.

title: Satellite derived estimates on methane emissions from rice paddies across China_supp1-3665059.pdf
authors: Zhang Xiuying
abstract: On the basis of Tro!pospheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) XCH4 columns, gridded methane (CH4) emissions from rice paddies across China were estimated in this study. The proposed method follows the principle of bottom-up analysis, and the key factor of methane emission rate was estimated from TROPOMI observations. Via the use of 175 data pairs of field-observed methane emission rates across paddy fields in China and the corresponding XCH4 enhancements in paddy fields compared with local background areas, a forward model was established, with a R2 value of 0.86 (p < 0.01). In 2019, the XCH4 enhancement in rice paddies than in local background areas at a 0.5°-resolution ranged from 0.04 to 16.57 ppb across China, and the mean methane emission rate reached 5.10 ± 3.29 mg CH4 m-2 yr-1, with high spatial variation across eastern China. Considering rice cultivate areas, the rice-growing season, and the estimated methane emission rates, the national methane emission from rice paddies was estimated to reach 5.88 Tg CH4 yr-1. The proposed method provides insights into the estimation of methane emissions from nonpoint sources on the basis of satellite observations.

title: Implementation of EAES using Image Key
authors: Srividya Ramisetty, Manu M N, M C Murali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Present communication scenarios promote efficiency and convenience of information processing, but the most important is, security regulations for communication as the data transmitted via various networks, including local or external LANs. Innumerable technologies have emerged for reliable communication. By utilizing both technologies, data can be transmitted seamlessly over the network. The main objective is to design a hybrid cipher combining steganography and existing ciphers to secure data transfer and unauthorized access. Data is stored and transmitted in a state-encrypted form using the state-of-the-art Extended Advanced Encryption Standard cipher using image key (EAESK) and then the least significant bit (LSB) is embedded to hide the data in the form of an image which is also a source of encryption key. To obtain a suitable stegano image, a separate wavelet is transmitted and sent to the receiver. Finally, the receiver performs a different set of procedures to extract the original information from ciphertext.

title: A Survey on Federated Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning for Large Language Models
authors: Quan Wen, Xiongtao Zhang, Nan Xiang, Jiwei Chen, Xun Wang, Jialong Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable efficacy across diverse domains, yet their deployment in sensitive sectors is constrained by data privacy. Federated Learning (FL) offers a promising paradigm for collaborative model training without exposing raw data, while Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) techniques substantially reduce adaptation costs. This survey systematically reviews the integration of FL and PEFT for LLMs, elucidating foundational architectures, mainstream PEFT methodologies, and federated adaptation frameworks. We analyze representative approaches, highlight open challenges, including communication bottlenecks, task and model heterogeneity, parameter anonymity, and adaptation profile misalignment, and propose future research directions. Our work aims to provide a comprehensive reference for advancing privacy-preserving, scalable, and efficient LLM fine-tuning in federated environments.

title: Relationship Extraction Based on BERT Model
authors: Jian Ai, Jia Liu, Beibei Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Relationship extraction is a key task in natural language processing and plays a critical role in building big data–driven prediction and decision-support systems. Faced with the vast amount of unstructured professional literature and regulatory texts in the tobacco industry, this paper proposes a BERT-based relation extraction method to automatically identify complex entity relations, such as ingredient–risk and gene–trait. By incorporating term-aware optimization strategies and structural information enhancement mechanisms, the model achieves higher accuracy and robustness in handling corpora with domain-specific terminology and complex sentence structures. Experimental results show that the proposed approach not only improves information extraction efficiency but also provides a reliable foundation for constructing industry-specific knowledge graphs, enabling intelligent regulatory analysis, risk prediction, and decision support in big data environments. This study demonstrates the practical value of applying AI-driven relation extraction to enhance prediction and decision-making capabilities in vertical industry big data applications.

title: The Impact of Livestream on the Relationship Customers and Brands
authors: Giang Tien Thi Nguyen, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: Sales through livestream sessions have become an important sales channel in e-commerce. This study explores the key factors influencing customer satisfaction, trust, and the strong relationship between customers and brands in livestream commerce, focusing on factors such as streamers, the interaction between parties during the live session, livestream quality, and, finally, the creativity presents in the livestream session. The study indicates that creativity in product presentation, particularly through engaging and innovative content, is the most important factor for customer satisfaction. Furthermore, livestream quality and real-time interaction were found to be crucial in enhancing trust and satisfaction, thereby strengthening the relationship between customers and brands. The research employs a mixed-method approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative methods. A survey questionnaire and in-depth interviews were used to collect information on students' evaluations and perspectives regarding the impact of livestream sales on customer-brand relationships. The results were analyzed using SPSS software to test the reliability of the measurement scales and examine which factors most significantly affect customer satisfaction, as well as the correlations between satisfaction, trust, and the relationship between customers and brands.

title: A Bandpass SIW Filter with Sharp Roll-off Rate and Wide Stopband
authors: Shiqi Jiang, Yuwei Zhang, Jinping Xu
abstract: In this letter, the design of a bandpass filter (BPF) based on substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) filter with sharp roll-off rate and wide stopband is proposed. The frequency selectivity of this SIW-based BPF is enhanced by loading periodic rectangular resonant slots etched on its top metal surface. Bandstop rejection microstrip structures are incorporated at the output end of the BPF to suppress the harmonics outside the passband. This design method is validated with a C-band bandpass filter incorporating an SIW cavity and four units of cycle-mirrored rectangular resonant slots. The measured S-parameters of the designed filter agree with the simulated ones. Leveraging the high-Q SIW cavity and periodic resonant units, the designed filter has achieved desired performance in terms of low insertion loss, sharp roll-off rate and wide stopband.

title: Regulatory Frameworks and Ethical Governance of Neural Networks in Computer Science Applications
authors: Gaurav Kumar, Rupam Kumari, Amit Shukla, Ajay Pratap Singh Yadav, Richa Verma, Jyoti Gaur
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The growing use of neural networks in vital industries including healthcare, banking, and government has increased worries about transparency, accountability, and adherence to international laws. There are a number of Responsible AI methods, but they frequently don't have a cohesive system in place to match technological design with moral and legal requirements at every stage of the model lifespan. In this research, we present the Regulation-Aware Neural Network Lifecycle (RANNL), a new five-stage paradigm that directly integrates explainability, bias mitigation, and real-time compliance tracking into neural network development. The Compliance Scoring System (CS) in RANNL, in contrast to previous methods, statistically assesses models according to their interpretability, fairness, and regulatory preparedness. The EU AI Act, UNESCO AI Ethics Recommendations, and OECD AI Principles are just a few of the international policies that are linked to each step of the lifespan by a dynamic Regulation Mapping Matrix.Using deep learning architectures and regulatory toolkits like AI Fairness 360, Captum, and SHAP, we apply RANNL to a real-world healthcare prediction problem in order to validate the scheme. Model openness, fairness metrics, and compliance scores are all improved without sacrificing predictive performance in comparison to traditional ML pipelines. These findings demonstrate how well RANNL may bridge the gap between global AI governance and neural network engineering. This paper offers an interdisciplinary, quantifiable, and scalable method for creating reliable AI systems by fusing technical and policy viewpoints.

title:
Wideband High-Power Class EF
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Power Amplifier Based on Multiple Series Resonance
authors: Sangyeop Kim, Sunwoo Nam, Yoonjung Lee, Seogyun Lim, Youngoo Yang
abstract: This paper presents a wideband Class-EF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> power amplifier (PA) based on a multiple series resonance (MSR) circuit. The proposed PA consists of a shunt capacitor, a series LC network in shunt, the MSR, and an impedance matching network, enabling simultaneous achievement of high efficiency, high output power, and wide bandwidth. In particular, the MSR is composed of multiple series resonance circuit with different resonance frequencies, which minimizes variations in output power and efficiency across the frequency band. To validate the wideband performance of the proposed MSR, Class-EF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> amplifier at a center frequency of 13.56 MHz was designed using an LDMOSFET. Using a continuous-wave (CW) signal, the implemented PA delivers a maximum output power of 59.2–60.0 dBm with a drain efficiency (DE) of from 79.3 to 86.7% over the 12.2–14.9 MHz band. Using a pulse with a duty cycle of 0.5, the output power and DE are increased to 59.6–60.2 dBm and 82.8–92.0% across the band, respectively. Thermal scan showed that the temperature maintained below 70 °C even for very high output power of more than 1 kW.

title: MPCL:Image-Text retrieval of multi-plane comparative learning
authors: Yifan Zeng, Haiwen Chen, Jibing Wu, Mao Wang, Hang Zhang, Yan Yu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: With the rapid development of information technology, massive amounts of multimodal data such as text and images are continuously generated and accumulated at an unprecedented rate. Against this backdrop, how to accurately and efficiently obtain the information required by users from massive data through image-text retrieval has become a core challenge in the field of information retrieval. Existing retrieval models often only attempt to align retrievals within a single semantic space. In this case, the probability of incorrect retrieval increases with the growth of data volume. This paper proposes an alignment method called MPCL(Multi-Plane Contrastive Learning), which tries to project data into different query vectors through cross-attention, enabling data alignment in multiple semantic spaces, thereby greatly improving the accuracy of retrieval. Experimental results show that the retrieval performance of the model improves as the number of query vectors increases.

title: Stability Evaluation Model of Surrounding Rock Mass in Underground Engineering Based on Fractal Interpolation-A Case Study of an Underground Chamber in a Granite Area of Tibet
authors: Chun Zhan, Peng Yang, Chenyu Li, Dong Li, Jun Liang, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The stability evaluation of surrounding rock is a core issue in the safety protection of underground engineering, essentially involving the study of system complexity characterized by multi-factor coupling and non-linearity. Given the limitations of traditional evaluation methods in terms of indicator compatibility, dynamic adaptability, and quantitative expression accuracy, this paper proposes a fractal-interpolation comprehensive evaluation model. First, five key control indicators are selected based on the principles of engineering geomechanics. Second, the fractal characteristic parameters of each indicator are determined using the box-counting dimension method from fractal theory, and an indicator-rating correlation matrix is established through the maximum likelihood criterion. Then, a fractal interpolation function is constructed to transform multi-dimensional indicators into a single fractal dimension evaluation index. Finally, a mapping relationship model between evaluation grades and fractal characteristic values is established. Taking an underground project in a granite area of Tibet as an example, the evaluation results of this method are not only consistent with traditional methods but also enable fine ranking of samples within the same grade through quantitative scoring. The study confirms that this model, by integrating fractal geometric features and interpolation approximation algorithms, effectively addresses the challenges of multi-source uncertainty factor fusion and dynamic evolution law characterization, providing a more accurate basis for decision-making in engineering practice.

title: The Role of Cognitive Skills in Phishing Detection: A Comparative Study Between Chess Players and Non-Chess Players
authors: Ioana Macovei, Susan Rea, Anila Mjeda, George D. O'Mahony
abstract: Phishing remains one of the most pervasive and effective techniques in real-world cyberattacks, leveraging human trust as the weakest link in security. Phishing attacks exploit fast, intuitive judgments. Drawing on the Dual Process Theories of Higher Cognition (DPT) of Evans and Stanovich, this original study investigates how cognitive strategies in chess can be applied to cybersecurity threat detection. In this research, chess players significantly outperform non-chess players at phishing detection, building on prior work where the two populations' cognitive abilities, such as cognitive reflection and planning, were studied. Using principles from Signal Detection Theory (SDT), the enhanced accuracy exhibited by chess players in identifying phishing emails appears more attributable to a generalized predisposition toward increased threat anticipation than to a domain-specific capacity to reliably discriminate between phishing and legitimate emails. Framed within the context of the Dual Process Theory and Signal Detection Theory, this perspective offers a novel insight into the cognitive mechanisms underlying cybersecurity decision-making, highlighting a potential role for chess-based cognitive expertise in phishing detection.

title: DMAS-KEP: Identifying Key Events and Critical Paths in Dynamic Multi-Agent Systems via Complex Networks
authors: Chao Liu, Weilong Yang, Yuan Wang, Jie Zhang, Liji Wu, Gongyu Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: This paper presents a novel lightweight framework for identifying key events and critical paths in dynamic multiagent system analysis by integrating complex network theory with multi-attribute decision making. Unlike traditional approaches that rely on macro-level statistics or limited centrality measures, our method constructs a comprehensive temporal weighted network from agent-event interactions, computes five complementary centrality dimensions (Degree, Betweenness, Closeness, K-Shell, and PageRank), and employs an entropy-weighted TOPSIS model for dynamic multi-criteria ranking and path extraction.The proposed framework was rigorously evaluated through a two-stage experimental process. First, its general capability for key node identification was validated on a suite of diverse, established complex networks, demonstrating superior performance against several state-of-the-art baselines in propagation tasks. Second, its specific efficacy for behavioral analysis was tested on a substantial corpus of professional multi-agent system simulation records, assessing its performance across the distinct strategic dimensions of agent confrontation, technological development, and resource regulation. Expert validation with domain specialists was conducted to gauge the practical utility and actionable insight of the system’s output.Expert validation confirms the framework’s practical utility, with 83% of identified key nodes receiving professional endorsement and 76% of behavioral suggestions deemed actionable. This work establishes a reproducible benchmark for complex system behavior analytics and demonstrates the effectiveness of combining complex networks with multi-dimensional decision theory for strategic analysis in complex multi-agent environments.

title: AI-Based Fault Diagnosis and Prediction of Power Switches
authors: Jin-Ju Lee, Bi Yu, Seong-Jong Kim, Dong-Hyeon Pyeon, Ho-Sub Lee, Hyun-Jun Choi
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This study proposes an AI-based Fault diagnosis and prediction algorithm that analyzes variations in the key electrical parameters of a power semiconductor switch to identify degradation progression and incipient fault symptoms. The proposed algorithm employs a hybrid neural architecture that combines a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) and a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to enable fault diagnosis detection and prediction for the power switch. MLP is configured to learn the static characteristics at each time step, LSTM is simultaneously to learn the dynamic changes over time. This approach enables high accuracy classification of MOSFET gate oxide degradation, packaging related degradation and normal operating states. In addition, modeling non-linear relationships with a polynomial regression model enables effective prediction of early degradation trends preceding fault occurrence. Based on MATLAB Simulink and NASA’s Open Data-Set, normal, degraded and fault states were collected. Consequently, the proposed algorithm was demonstrated by simulation results with a small gap between training and validation losses and a diagnostic accuracy exceeding 96%.

title: An X-band GaAs Low Noise Amplifier
authors: Jiyoung Lee, Hewa Maddumage Ishath Harshika, Gwanghyeon Jeong, Minjae Kim, Dong-Ho Lee
abstract: This paper presents a compact monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) low-noise amplifier (LNA) designed for X-band applications, operating between 8GHz and 10.5GHz. Fabricated using 0.25-μm GaAs pHEMT technology, the LNA occupies a small footprint of 1.44mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and employs a self-biased, three-stage design. It achieves a low noise figure of 1.27-1.52dB and a gain of 27-29.1dB at 8-10.5GHz. The paper discusses the circuit architecture, bias network, and noise figure behavior, and the nonlinear characteristics of the MMIC. Operating from a 3V supply and consuming 34mA, the design offers a compact and efficient solution for X-band systems.

title: Multimodal Learning for Predicting Fat Component Shifts in Kyrgyz Women across Different Ages
authors: Nazgul Tashmatova, Kyialbek Sakibaev, Akmaral Argynbaeva, UulkanManas Kyzy, AltynaiTopchubai Kyzy, Tatyana Grichanova
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This investigation forms a multimodal deep learning architecture which combines Vision Transformers (ViT) based deep learning architecture for DEXA scan analysis with the TabNet model for the integration of anthropometric measurements, hormonal profiles and lifestyle factors to estimate the reconstruction of age related adipose tissue redistribution for Kyrgyz women. We realise a fusion mechanism based on cross attention using MONAI framework for medical image preprocessing and PyTorch Lightning for 8450 patient records of longitudinal data. The model is based on temporal convolutional network (TCN) for capturing the ageing pattern and Optuna for the hyperparameter optimization and the final accuracy for the transition of visceral-subcutaneous fat ratio is 94.2 %. Feature importance analysis using SHAP values leads to the identification of important biomarkers like oestrogen levels, dietary patterns and genetic polymorphisms. The pipeline makes use of Weights & Biases to be able to store and keep track of the experiment and TorchServe for deployment to Azure Machine Learning for release of the model so that it can be experimented in real time to assess the risk. Interpretable Interventions Based on the explainable AI capabilities of Captum, clinically interpretable insights can be derived to generate the validation of the intervention plan of individual patients relative to clinical 5 Year Follow-up data antifrauder results finding 89% predictive concordance.

title: Innovative Pedagogical Strategies in Science Education: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence for Enhanced Digital Literacy
authors: Seema Kushwah, Khaldi Zakarya, El Ganich Said, Elly Rizeqia Fadilah, B V Ravichandra, Raman K Attri
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The rapid technological advancement, in particular, the emergence of artificial intelligence (AI), is transforming education and requires manipulation of innovative pedagogical methods to meet the evolving requirements of science education. In this essay, the researcher examines how AI can be effectively implemented to enhance the digital literacy of students and facilitate a better understanding of science. By integrating adaptive learning platforms, data-driven feedback processes and intelligent tutoring systems, teachers may promote inquiry-based learning strategies and personalise learning processes. Another aspect of AI development that the project explores via interactive simulation and virtual laboratories is the possibility of AI to support differentiated learning, facilitate real-time feedback, and enhance student interaction. The development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical reasoning skills are noted as essential to the digital literacy of the 21 st century. Using recent studies and case studies, the study provides the best practices and potential challenges in implementing AI-based tactics in different educational settings. Ultimately, our work is based on a paradigm shift in science education in favor of AI as a transformative agent to produce students who are future-ready, digitally literate, and scientifically literate. The findings indicate the need to have purposeful policy frameworks and continuous professional growth among educators to help them incorporate AI in science curricula in a morally and successfully integrated manner.

title: An Integrated Shield Flip-Chip Mounting MIC Bandpass Filter in Q-Band
authors: Yu Kanamori, Tamotsu Nishino, Noriharu Suematsu
abstract: In order to meet the demand for high frequencies above the Q-band in non-terrestrial communication networks in 5G and Beyond 5G, we prototyped a flip-chip mounted Q-band bandpass filter on an alumina substrate MIC with an integrated shield structure. There are problems due to spatial radiation from the resonators in high frequency filters, and loading of shield plates or packaging are usually adopting at the expense of increasing size. An integrated shield structure is realized by using vias and a GND layer inside the resin substrate on which other devices can be mounted. The proposed structure could solve both the radiation problem and miniaturization. The prototype showed high rejection characteristics outside the passband, and sufficient steepness. The simulation and measurement of the prototype showed good agreements, confirming the effectiveness of the integrated shield structure.

title: A Frequency-Reconfigurable Multi-Band 4-Channel Beamforming IC for Millimeter-Wave 5G Communication
authors: Gyuha Lee, Hyoungkyu Jin, Jaehun Lee, Eun-Taek Sung, Songcheol Hong
abstract: A frequency-reconfigurable (FR) multi-band 4-channel beamforming IC (BFIC) fabricated using a 28-nm CMOS process is presented. It integrates four FR transceiver beamforming channels with fully differential wideband common components of a 4-way power divider/combiner and channel switches. Each channel consists of FR-type components as well as wideband ones to cover multiple bands. FR-type ones include power amplifier, variable gain phase shifter, and driver amplifiers, while wideband ones include low-noise amplifier and antenna switch. The BFIC has 6-/4-bit phase/gain control resolution and a 15 dB gain control range, with the measured RMS phase errors of 1.57/1.59° and RMS gain errors of 0.24/0.24 dB at 26.5/37 GHz. It achieves noise figures of 5.8 and 5.5 dB, linear output powers of 7.3 and 3.3 dBm with a 64-quadrature amplitude modulation 100-MHz signal at 26.5 and 37 GHz, respectively.

title: A Multimodal Dynamic Interaction-Based Method for Indoor Scene Recognition
authors: Zijian Chen, Miao Jia, Jintao Liao, Hang Du
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Indoor scene recognition has achieved significant progress with deep learning, but existing methods often suffer from imbalanced modality contributions, neglect of feature differences across modalities, and insufficient cross-scale semantic consistency. To address these issues, we propose Mul-DGM, a multi-modal dynamic interaction model for indoor scene recognition. Mul-DGM employs a dual-branch architecture with ResNet-50 for RGB feature extraction and Swin Transformer for normal map feature extraction. A dynamic modality interaction enhancement (DMIE) module adaptively balances modality contributions through bidirectional attention and dynamic routing, while a global adaptive cross-modal attention (GACMA) module leverages multi-head attention to effectively capture complementary characteristics across modalities. Furthermore, a multi-scale modality contrastive loss (MSMCL) is introduced to enforce semantic consistency across different scales. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that Mul-DGM achieves superior accuracy and generalization compared to state-of-the-art approaches, validating the effectiveness of the proposed modules in robust multi-modal feature fusion for indoor scene recognition.

title: Employing Neural Networks to Predict Coronary Heart Disease Based on Physiological Parameters
authors: Sheela Hundekari, Sachin Etam, Purshottam Hoovayya, M Madhu Babu, Prathamesh H Kamble, Isha Das
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The most lethal illness and one of the main causes of death in the world is heart disease. Heart-related conditions that affect the organ's structure and operation collectively go under the umbrella term “heart disease.” Whenever the heart's arteries cannot adequately supply the organ with oxygen-rich blood, coronary heart disease, a kind of heart disease, develops. In the discipline of medicine, machine learning is crucial. The performance of heart disease prediction is improved in this study using ensemble learning techniques. A wrong diagnosis can kill, but being able to predict heart disease correctly can lower major health risks. This study analyses the outcomes and analyses of the University of California at Irvine Machine Learning Cardiovascular Syndrome Dataset by a range of machine learning and deep learning approaches. The dataset consists of the 14 key characteristics that will be employed in the investigation. It is possible to verify some encouraging results using accuracy and confusion matrices. The study's findings were contrasted with those of the most recent, state-of-the-art research, with an emphasis on how well they predicted heart disease. In this study, a deep learning technique called “neural networks” is forecast the probability of cardiovascular ailment in a patient. The outcomes demonstrate that the wished-for model achieves improvements to the currently used approaches mentioned in this study. The suggested model's overall accuracy for categorical and binary models produces 80.3% and 83.6%.

title: MIRA: A 5T1C Flash Cell-based Mixed-Signal InMemory Readout Architecture Achieving Highly Accurate VMM Computation
authors: Hyung-Min Kim, Chan-Woong Park, Kee-Won Kwon
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: In-memory computing (IMC) offers an efficient alternative to von-Neumann architectures by performing multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations directly within memory arrays. To enable reliable analog VMM operations, this work presents MIRA, a mixed-signal in-memory readout architecture based on highly stable 5T1C Flash synaptic cells programmed using a Constant-Pulse Programming (CPP) scheme. Implemented in a $\mathbf{1 8 0}-\mathbf{n m}$ CMOS process and validated through HSPICE co-simulation, MIRA sequentially processes a $16 \times 16$ Flash VMM array, where accumulated synaptic currents are converted by a high-linearity CVE, serialized through a frequency-divider-controlled MUX, and digitized by a compact 4-bit flash ADC. Monte Carlo results demonstrate excellent MAC linearity ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{\gt} \mathbf{0. 9 9 5 7}$) under device variations, confirming accurate Flash conductance-tovoltage mapping.

title: Bidirectional Converter for Electric Vehicles based on Matrix-Type Rectifier and Interleaved CLLLC
authors: Yufei Wu, Jiaxing Lei, Chenyu Zhang, Jianyu Yu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of large loss, low power density, and complicated control of bidirectional operation in traditional electric vehicles, a high-efficiency bidirectional converter for electric vehicles based on a matrix rectifier and interleaved CLLLC is proposed. The front-stage matrix rectifier structure significantly reduces the switching loss of the converter, and the back-stage interleaved CLLLC resonant converter is easily operated in a wide range of forward and reverse directions. However, the six-pulse wave voltage of the matrix rectifier makes the output voltage contain low-frequency pulsations. A joint modulation strategy is proposed to utilize the linearized gain curve for feed-forward control, which accurately counteracts the effects of bus voltage pulsations and yields a smooth and adjustable output voltage. Finally, a simulation model verifies the effectiveness of the proposed topology and method.

title: Design of a 40-110 GHz Ultra-Wideband Wilkinson Power Divider with Low Insertion Loss
authors: Libo Zheng, Yan Jiang, Haowei Xie, Yufeng Guo
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Based on a 100 nm GaAs process, this study presents an ultra-wideband Wilkinson power divider (WPD) with low insertion loss (IL) covering 40-110 GHz. EM simulations demonstrate that the power divider achieves an IL of less than 1 dB across the operating band, with return loss (RL) and isolation better than 10 dB at all ports. Specifically, S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf> remains below -15 dB from 54 to 103 GHz, while S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">22</inf> and S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">33</inf> are both below -15 dB in the 40–103 GHz range. Moreover, the isolation exceeds 15 dB between 57 and 120 GHz.

title: Load-Aware and QoS-Constrained Task Scheduling Method for Edge Computing in Power Systems
authors: Jiaqi Chen, Guoqiang Zhang, Wheichen Liu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the problem of low computational efficiency caused by unbalanced loads and latency sensitivity of computing tasks in distribution grid automation and microgrid control within smart grid edge computing environments, this paper proposes a latency-constrained task allocation algorithm. First, the data size of each power monitoring and control task and its transmission latency to edge computing nodes are analyzed, and the queuing time for each task is calculated. Then, based on the NSGA-III multi-objective optimization algorithm, an optimal tasks scheduling sequence within virtual machine queues is determined, using total queuing time as the criterion. This method ensures both load balancing among virtual machines and fulfillment of QoS latency requirements for critical power applications. Finally, simulation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in improving computational efficiency and guaranteeing latency performance in power system scenarios.

title: Optimal Scheduling of Virtual Power Plant Based on Humpback Whale Migration Algorithm
authors: Yu Xing, Jiming Tian
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Virtual Power Plants (VPPs) integrate distributed energy resources (DERs) such as photovoltaic (PV), wind power, gas turbines, energy storage, and flexible loads to participate in electricity markets through coordinated optimization. This paper proposes a dispatch optimization model for VPPs based on the Humpback Whale Migration Algorithm (WMA), a metaheuristic inspired by whale migration behaviors. The model aims to minimize total operation costs while considering energy balance, generator constraints, start-up/shut-down costs, and market electricity prices. Comparative simulations demonstrate that WMA achieves faster convergence and better global search capability than traditional particle swarm optimization (PSO) and genetic algorithms (GA), effectively improving the VPP’s economic operation and flexibility.

title: Deep-Learning-Based X-Band Waveguide Permittivity Measurement Method for Dielectric Materials with Air Gaps
authors: Seonguk Kwon, Jungbin Seo, Handong Seo, Hyemin Yang, Chaejin Lee, Youngcheol Park
abstract: This paper proposes a convolutional neural network (CNN) model for accurate permittivity estimation of dielectric materials with air gaps in X-band waveguide measurements. The model extends the conventional Nicolson-Ross-Weir method by training on S-parameter data under non-ideal conditions, including samples with air gaps. Performance validation using FR-4 substrates demonstrates error rates within 4.6% for samples with air gaps up to 5%, confirming the approach as a robust solution for practical permittivity measurements of dielectric materials with air gaps.

title: WasteNet: A Structured-Pruned and EMA-Augmented RepVGG Framework for Real-Time Trash Classification
authors: Yaragani Neelima, Kakumanu Sravani, Kondavarju Ramya, Chinthalanka Poojitha, Akila Venkatraman, Yerrarapu Sravani Devi, Dr.Sireesha Moturi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Achieving efficient classification of garbage boosts recycling and helps with pollution control as well as sustainable waste management. To address this challenge,we developed RepVGG-MEM, which is a lightweight and highly accurate Deep Learning model for real-time waste classification. Built on RepVGG, the model applies EMA,Mixup data augmented training, and structured pruning to optimization to maintain a strong speed performance ratio. The model and its described metrics, performance of 95.06% accuracy and a 94.5% F1 score, even with closely resembling waste categories surpass several previous versions. Moreover, its accuracy makes it ideal for edge devices and smart mobile waste management systems.RepVGG-MEM shows better performance and generalization than earlier versions. Its lightweight design makes it easy to deploy on edge devices such as smart bins and mobile platforms. This capability positions it as a promising solution for automated waste management in real-world situations.

title: Graph Neural Networks-Mapped Code Optimization System for Software Performance
authors: J. Pavithra, Gokulakrishnan G, Jetlin C P, H. Mickle Aancy, S.V. Telrandhe, Sowmya P D
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper has demonstrated a deep reinforcement learning-based framework of power flow optimization on smart grids based on Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm in the Grid2Op simulation environment. Tergy variability and Real Time Contingencies. Facing to these issues, the use of PPO is made, because of its stability and the efficiency of the sample in continuous action spaces to make the adaptive redispatch decisions with the lowest operational costs and the compliance of voltage and thermal constraints. Grid2Op provides a realistic grid simulation environment of dynamic system, contingencies and operator actions where the agent learns robust policies by interactions with the environment in a sequential manner. Results show that the proposed PPO based framework is able to have a good balance between operational security and efficiency and nearly optimal power flow solutions with less violations and more flexibility in front of uncertainty. This is the combination points out the possibility of using sophisticated RL algorithms, combined with domainspecific simulation tools for resilient and real-time smart grid control.

title: Analysis of Lightning Electromagnetic Field Propagation Characteristics Considering the Topography and Geomorphology of Guangdong Province
authors: Xiangyang Peng, Yuan Zhou, Yazhou Fan
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Current research on lightning electromagnetic field inversion largely overlooks the influence of terrain and soil conductivity on propagation. This paper therefore employs the Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) algorithm to construct a propagation model for lightning electromagnetic fields, utilising actual terrain and soil conductivity distribution data from Guangdong Province. The model's accuracy was validated through artificial lightning induction experiments, and the study analysed how Guangdong's real terrain and soil conductivity distribution affect the propagation characteristics of lightning electromagnetic fields.

title: Predicting Hourly Electricity Demand Using Fuzzy Logic: Integrating Environmental Factors for Accurate Forecasting
authors: Ahmed Intekhab Rohan, Md Ismail Hossain, Hasanur Zaman Anonto, Abu Shufian, Mohammad Shah Paran, Toriqul Islam, Md Shakhawat Hossain
abstract: This study investigates the distribution of electricity demand is distributed over temperature, humidity, wind speed and seasonal variations. Using data covering the timeframe of five years (2021-2025), the objective behind this research is to understand the interdependent nature of the electric demand and different external conditions of the environment. Preliminary analysis indicates that the demand for electricity varies based on the time of the day, the season and the day of the week. Peak demand is at noon in winter at 27,000 units and declines to 22,000 units during post-midnight. Electric demand positively correlated with temperature and humidity, where a notable increase in demand was detected when temperature increased from 5°C to 8°C and when humidity increased from 60% to 66% The wind speed variation of the demand shows that the demand is less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and higher than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The impact of the seasonal change is also studied in this paper and the results show that the demand is higher in the winter and summer due to the heating and cooling need respectively while the demand is lower in the spring and autumn. The findings deliver specific intelligence on optimizing how energy management strategies can best be employed, specifically for ensuring that demand drops are anticipated ahead of time around peak seasons and extreme weather.

title: Ka-Band Omnidirectional Circularly Polarized Waveguide Slot Antenna for Low-Altitude UAV Applications
authors: Jinlun Li, Yuqing Zhu, Chengcheng Yu, Hongxin Zhao
abstract: This work presents a Ka-Band omnidirectional right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) antenna with two circular plates excited by slots. Eight inclined slots are uniformly etched along the circumference of the circular waveguide. The omnidirectional RHCP is achieved by exciting TEM and TE waves with different phase constants between two plates. The gradient structures and grooves on two plates are employed to control beam coverage and optimize the beam shape in the lower hemisphere. Additionally, a transition from the TE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</inf> mode of rectangular waveguide to the TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</inf> mode of circular waveguide is designed to feed the antenna. To validate the design, a prototype is fabricated and measured. The measurement results show that the proposed antenna achieves omnidirectional RHCP characteristics with horizontal roundness lower than 2.5 dB and axial ratio lower than 3.5 dB from 35.2 to 36.4 GHz. Furthermore, the elevation beam covers from -10° to +30°, which is preferred by low-altitude UAVs.

title: Data-Driven Approach for Dynamic Comparator in Analog-to-Digital Conversion
authors: Buddhi Prakash Dharma, Anu Gupta, Chandra Shekhar
abstract: The performance of dynamic comparators significantly influences the efficiency, speed, and accuracy of Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs), especially in modern low-power and high-speed applications. Traditional design methodologies relying on exhaustive simulations and manual tuning are inefficient and fail to adapt to process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations. This paper proposes a comprehensive data-driven optimization framework that leverages machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance dynamic comparator performance across key metrics. The framework introduces a four-stage pipeline comprising feature extraction from simulation and measurement data, supervised learning for offset voltage prediction, reinforcement learning (RL) for adaptive calibration, and Bayesian optimization for automated sizing of circuit components. These methods collectively reduce design complexity, improve accuracy and power efficiency, and enable real-time adaptability. While integration with Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools remains a future direction, the proposed framework lays the foundation for scalable, intelligent comparator design targeting applications such as IoT, biomedical systems, and high-speed communications.

title: Analysis of Probe Coupling for Channel Property Optimization in an HVAC Duct
authors: Dong-Min Seo, Ji-Hoon Lee, Hyo-Won Lee, Ji-Young Kim, Jong-Won Yu
abstract: This paper investigates how different probe configurations influence signal coupling inside cylindrical heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) ducts. A set of representative probes (monopole, Yagi-Uda, dipole, and patch) are examined through electromagnetic simulations and measurements conducted in an 8-meter galvanized steel duct (30 cm diameter) operating at 2.4–2.5 GHz. By varying the feed positions and probe heights across multiple configurations, the study identifies the key physical parameters that govern mode excitation and coupling efficiency under realistic conditions. The analysis reveals that geometrical alignment and radiative behavior significantly impact signal transmission characteristics and overall channel quality. The BLT equation is applied to the duct model and validated against measured data, enabling scalable analysis of extended duct lengths beyond conventional simulation limits.

title: AAP2-YOLO: A Model Improvement about Counter-UAV Detection
authors: Xiang Hu, Xinding Zhang, Jianmin Hu, Chen Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In response to the challenges of Counter-UAV (C-UAV) target detection in the security domain—specifically the small size of UAVs and their susceptibility to background interference—this paper proposes an improved YOLOv11-based algorithm, termed AAP2-YOLO, to enhance the detection performance of small UAVs. The proposed method incorporates three key optimization strategies: (1) the introduction of the ADown module into the backbone as a down-sampling component, which reduces parameter count while mitigating feature loss during extraction; (2) the replacement of the original neck with a more efficient ASF network, enabling effective multi-scale feature fusion; and (3) structural modifications involving the removal of the large-scale detection head and its associated neck layers, along with the addition of a P2 detection layer, which substantially improves small-object detection performance. Experimental results on the DUT ANTI-UAV dataset demonstrate that AAP2-YOLO outperforms YOLOv11n, achieving an 11.6% increase in Recall and a 9% improvement in mAP50, while simultaneously reducing parameter count by 36%. To further validate the generalization ability of the proposed model, we included additional inference experiments on the TIB-Net UAV dataset in the comparative analysis. The results further demonstrate that, for small-object detection, the proposed model achieves superior performance compared with mainstream approaches. Although inference complexity increases, the overall frame rate remains within the real-time range, making the method suitable for deployment on embedded devices.

title: EEG-Based Classification of Abnormal Epileptiform Patterns
authors: R.H. Sanjay, Harshita Patel, Dharmendra Singh Rajput
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a widely used non-invasive technique for monitoring brain activity, especially for diagnosing neurological disorders like epilepsy. However, EEG interpretation remains a complex and time-intensive task due to the high variability and noise inherent in the signals. This study proposes a comparative evaluation of two state-of-the-art classification models-CatBoost, a gradient boosting machine learning algorithm, and WaveNet, a deep learning architecture designed for temporal sequence modeling-for automated detection of abnormal epileptiform EEG patterns. Utilizing the publicly available HMS EEG dataset, both models are assessed on classification accuracy and computational efficiency. Results show that WaveNet outperforms CatBoost in classification accuracy, achieving a cross-validation score of 0.81 versus 0.74, though it incurs significantly higher computational cost. Conversely, CatBoost offers faster inference and enhanced model interpretability, making it more suitable for real-time clinical deployment. The study highlights key trade-offs between performance and efficiency, suggesting potential for hybrid approaches that leverage the strengths of both models to advance reliable, explainable, and scalable EEG-based epilepsy diagnosis systems.

title: An Innovative Electric Vehicle Charging System Using Game-Theoretic Optimization Model and Pre-Connection SOC Modeling
authors: Netrananda Behera, Sk Sharmila, Mohammad Musa Al-Momani, Navyatha Ravi, Anandhi R J, S Kaliappan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To manage widespread Electric vehicle (EV) charging efficiently while ensuring grid stability, we designed the proposed IECGPS model introduces a model for Intelligent Electric Vehicle Charging and Grid Power Scheduling (IECGPS). The specification system limits, including minimum and maximum charging rates for each EV and voltage thresholds to maintain distribution system stability. It uses a dataset of over eighteen million EV charging sessions, considering factors like power delivered, charging duration, and the state of charge (SoC) of the vehicles. A pre-connection SoC model predicts the initial battery levels of EVs to better forecast their future charging needs based on previous travel data and energy usage. By combining Energy storage systems (ESS) and the processes of EV charging and discharging into an optimization framework using game-theory principles. EVs communicate their energy needs and costs, and the energy management system coordinates their charging and discharging schedules while considering grid support and contributions from wind energy. This optimization aims to enhance EV user satisfaction by addressing charging and discharging requirements while reducing costs linked to renewable energy integration. The experimental calculation using wind speed, output power, satisfaction rate, overall result of the IECGPS model, and the ROC curve.

title: TBNet-Lite: A Lightweight Artificial Learning System for Automatic TB Detection
authors: Pragathi Bellamkonda, Priyadarsan Parida, Manoj Kumar Panda, Ranjita Rout, Ajit Kumar Patro
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Tuberculosis (TB) continues to be a major global health concern, particularly in regions with limited access to diagnostic expertise and healthcare infrastructure. While chest X-ray (CXR) imaging is a valuable diagnostic modality for early TB screening, the manual interpretation of radiographs often introduces variability. It depends heavily on the availability of skilled radiologists. In response to this challenge, we propose a novel deep convolutional neural network (CNN) designed to classify CXR images as TB-positive or TB-negative automatically. The architecture integrates a residual-style framework comprising dual-branch convolutional layers featuring both 3 × 3 and 1 × 1 convolutions to facilitate effective feature extraction and enhance representational depth. LeakyReLU (LR) activation functions and batch normalization (BN) are employed throughout the model to improve training stability and mitigate gradient degradation. A global average pooling (GAP) layer is used for spatial dimension reduction, followed by a fully connected classification head. The model is trained and evaluated on publicly available TB CXR datasets using standard performance metrics, including accuracy, specificity, sensitivity, and F1-score. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves superior performance compared to prior methods. Given its computational efficiency and reliability, the model shows promise for integration into real-time, low-resource diagnostic settings as a supportive tool for TB screening.

title: GAN-Based Rare Disease Image Synthesis: A Solution for Data Scarcity and Privacy-Aware Learning
authors: Harshita Kumari, Monalisa Jena, Ranjan Kumar Behera
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have emerged as a powerful deep learning paradigm for synthetic data generation, addressing critical challenges associated with real-world datasets, including scarcity, privacy risks, and high collection costs. This paper presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of a GAN-based framework capable of producing realistic and diverse synthetic datasets for applications in computer vision and machine learning. The study elaborates on the adversarial training process between the Generator and the Discriminator, providing a structured workflow and sample outputs to illustrate the fidelity of the generated data. Experimental results demonstrate notable improvements in dataset diversity and highlight potential applications in data augmentation, anomaly detection, and privacy-preserving learning. It is evident that GAN-generated synthetic data can effectively complement real-world datasets and enhance model performance, though persistent challenges such as training instability, mode collapse, and reliable quality evaluation remain open research issues. This paper addresses both the practical utility and the broader research significance of GANs in advancing synthetic data generation.

title: Machine Learning Driven Dynamic Pricing System for E-Commerce Revenue Optimization
authors: A. Bhuvaneshwari, NinadMurlidhar Gawande, Naveen Nandal, A U Nitha, Sannet Thomas, Vijay Uprikar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Pricing in the dynamic and competitive environment of e-commerce is extremely important in maintaining profitability and customer satisfaction. This study introduces a Dynamic Pricing System powered by Machine Learning that should be used to maximize the revenue by making smart, data-based price changes. The framework uses Z-Score Normalization to preprocess the data and treat similarities of different input transactional data and Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) to identify the most significant pricing features. The main prediction model will be a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network combined with an Attention Mechanism, which is capable of successfully modeling time relationships and market changes. The proposed system has a higher forecasting accuracy and lower error rates and greater adaptability as implemented in TensorFlow, which is more efficient than traditional models. Experimental measurements prove that there are high levels of enhancement in pricing accuracy, revenue increment, and retention of customers. The research creates a strong scalable solution in real-time dynamic pricing within the ever-changing e-commerce environment.

title: AI-Integrated Drone Swarm Coordination Using Deep Q-Networks for Disaster Response
authors: S.S. Suganya, Arasan A, Arthi V, Ashelyfiego S, Deepak M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: While disaster response necessitates rapid aerial surveillance and scalable operations, present heuristic or rule-based drone control systems have limited adaptability, a high chance of collision, and low energy efficiency. To address these limitations, it provides an AIembedded swarm system that leverages Deep Q-Networks (a sort of reinforcement learning). It uses prioritized experience replay, dueling structures, and battery-aware reward structuring to allow them to collaborate in detecting victims while dynamically modifying their path at a low cost. A comparison examination demonstrates enhanced performance when compared to heuristic routing and attention-driven AD3QN. The results demonstrate an 18 % improvement in detection rate, a 59 % reduction in collision frequency, and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 41 \%$</tex> increase in mission range. These results indicate that reinforcement learning-driven swarm coordination is a potential method for increasing the safety, adaptability, and efficiency of these systems in real-world disaster response applications.

title: GaN Power Amplifier MMICs for Upper D-Band Communications
authors: Philipp Neininger, Thomas Zieciak, Peter Brückner, Michael Mikulla, Rüdiger Quay
abstract: In this paper, we describe the design considerations, the 70-nm GaN process and measurement results of three advanced upper D-band PA MMICs. Starting with a 5-stage baseline design that uses one output transistor, we develop a 2-way and 4-way power combined version using both reactive power combining and a directional coupler and compare their results. The 2-way MMIC PA2 delivers up to 22.2 Bm at 145 GHz and a PAE of up to 7.6 %. Moreover, the 4-way MMIC PA3 delivers up to 23.1 dBm at both 140 and 145 GHz with an associated PAE of up to 4.9 %. Compared to the state of the art, these values are on par with or exceed any GaN-based PAs reported so far.

title: A Wideband, Low-Loss, and Highly Reliable Supportless Air-Filled Coax-to-Waveguide Transition With Monolithic 3-D Printing Integration
authors: Ziyang Lin, Jin Li, Zhentao Xie, Zhihong Xu, Tao Yuan
abstract: This paper presents a novel structural design for wideband and low-loss air-filled coax-to-waveguide transitions realized through 3-D printing technology. The proposed transition structure enhances mechanical reliability by optimizing the termination of the air-filled coaxial line’s inner conductor, thereby eliminating suspended features and reducing deformation risks as well as fabrication sensitivity. It also overcomes bandwidth limitations caused by internal supporting stubs of the inner conductor by introducing a supportless air-filled coaxial architecture, where the inner conductor is inherently supported by the waveguide wall. A Ka-band back-to-back transition prototype, fabricated using Polyjet 3-D printing and electroless copper/silver plating, achieves a return loss exceeding 15 dB and an average insertion loss of 0.78 dB across the full band. These results confirm the proposed design’s potential for high-reliability RF measurement and applications involving 3-D printed air-filled coaxial components.

title: Neuro-Swarm Diffusion Reinforcement with Probabilistic Eco-Adaptive Modeling for Coastal Flood Risk Management
authors: Ravi Selshi Angel, Kalaivani K, Abdul Basith K, Karan Babaso Patil, Sumaiya Samreen, Hyma Lakshmi T V
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The climate change and eco-varying causes floods that occur along the coasts to be unpredictable. The aim of the research is to create dynamic and uncertaintyconscious logic of precise prediction and control of flood risks. The paper presents a new model and proposed research namely Eco-Adaptive Neuro-Swarm Flood Management Framework (EANS-FM), a new framework that integrates Neuro-Swarm Diffusion Reinforcement that enables maximized and adaptive policy achievement and Probabilistic Eco-Adaptive Modeling which handles ecological uncertainty. This framework is tested on the basis of the Coastal Climate Risk Dataset that consists of geospatial, climatic, and ecological characteristics. Findings indicate that EANS-FM has a prediction root of 98.98 percent with the ability of adjusting to the dynamic environmental factors and deliver dependable measurements of the flood risks. All in all, the study offers a strong, real time, and ecologically knowledgeable remedy to coastal flooding management pointing to the fact that it integrates adaptative learning and ecological uncertainty modeling into one.

title: Ferrite-Free High-Power Balun for Differential Push-Pull Amplifiers in MRI/NMR Applications
authors: Ouadie Touijer, Alexander Schönecker, Jens Löffler, Philipp Wiedemann, Norman Franchi, Georg Fischer
abstract: This paper presents the development of a compact, ferrite-free, high-performance balun designed for operation at 128 MHz. The design employs a low-impedance coaxial structure for effective impedance transformation and incorporates a passive matching network for optimal adaptation to standard system impedances. Full-wave electromagnetic (EM) simulations and single-ended S-parameter measurements demonstrate a common-mode rejection ratio exceeding 20 dB and an insertion loss of approximately 0.7 dB. The balun is specifically developed for use in push-pull amplifier architectures that avoid ferromagnetic materials, such as those used in magnetic resonance systems. The design fulfills the key requirements of low insertion loss, high symmetry, and high power handling capability.

title: Automatic Extraction of Ground Target Features from High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images Based on the TransU-Net Model
authors: Guanglong Tian, Angze Li, Jiafu Yan, Yaobin Liu, Zhizhi Zhang, Zhongshun Cai
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of remote sensing science and satellite technology, multi-target extraction techniques based on optical remote sensing imagery have achieved remarkable progress, providing robust support for geological remote sensing interpretation. The technical approach has evolved from basic visual interpretation to the current dominance of deep learning. However, in geological surveys, visual interpretation remains the most frequently used extraction method in operational workflows. To explore the application of automatic ground target extraction techniques in geological surveys, this paper proposes a novel solution incorporating advanced neural network architectures—the TransU-Net model. Building upon an improved U-Net framework, this model integrates the global modeling capability of Transformer networks, effectively combining the strengths of both architectures. Experimental results demonstrate that the TransU-Net model significantly enhances the accuracy of ground target extraction in geological remote sensing imagery, offering more reliable technical support for related applications.

title: RCS Measurement and Modeling of Manned Electric Bicycle in the 77-81 GHz Band
authors: Mengdi Wu, Zhengbo Jiang, Junping Zhu, Shangbing Qiao, Tong Liu
abstract: Radar Cross Section (RCS) quantifies a target's electromagnetic wave scattering capability, serving as a fundamental metric for millimeter-wave automotive radar systems in target detection and identification. Currently, open literature lacks comprehensive characterization of RCS for typical road objects such as manned electric bicycles in the W-band. This paper presents 77-81 GHz field measurements of manned electric bicycle RCS using advanced post-processing, with a novel statistical framework quantifying their distribution characteristics through Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) modeling. The proposed RCS statistical model demonstrates excellent consistency with the experimental data, providing a robust theoretical foundation for the design and optimization of target detection and recognition algorithms in automotive radar systems.

title: Research on the Stability of Multi-Machine System of Grid-type Converter
authors: Zile Wang, Xiaoping Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper investigates the small-signal stability of multi-converter grid-forming (GFM) systems operating in weak grids and proposes a hierarchical, coordination-based parameter optimization strategy. First, an accurate multi-GFM modeling framework is established: a control-aware dq-domain small-signal model for each converter, positive/negative-sequence impedance representations, and a network-coupled nodal-admittance formulation are integrated into a global state-space model that enables eigenvalue and participation-factor analysis. Using this framework, we identify and classify dominant oscillation modes—device-level (200–230 Hz), cluster-interaction (≈35–55 Hz), and global power oscillations (≈1–10 Hz)—and quantify how virtual inertia J, damping D, line impedance/Short-Circuit Ratio(SCR), and controller dispersion shape modal damping and energy participation. Building on these insights, we design a two-layer optimization: (i) local impedance-based tuning to guarantee standalone margins, and (ii) system-level coordination via particle swarm optimization over {J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>,D<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>,k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">pv,i</inf>,k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">iv,i</inf>} to maximize the minimum modal damping. Time-domain and modal results on a three-GFM benchmark show that the proposed strategy increases the worst-case damping ratio from 0.041 to 0.072 (+75.6%), reduces peak frequency deviation under a 5% load step from 0.118 Hz to 0.061 Hz, and shortens settling time from 1.20 s to 0.63 s. Robustness tests across SCR = 6.0→2.0 keep ξ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">min</inf>>0.06 and Δf<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf><0.06 Hz without sacrificing steady-state regulation, validating scalability and applicability to weak networks.

title: Indoor Localization Using Extended Kalman Filter with Time-of-Arrival Measurements
authors: Lang Zhang, Ze Li, Zengshan Tian, Yu Zhang
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive simulation study of an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for high-precision localization of a mobile target based on Time-of-Arrival (TOA) measurements. The system integrates a nonlinear kinematic model with noisy TOA data from multiple fixed anchor nodes to estimate the state vector, encompassing position, heading angle, linear velocity, and angular velocity. A novel data association algorithm addresses challenges arising from noisy and misassociated observations, ensuring robust state estimation. Performance is evaluated through detailed trajectory tracking and position error analysis. The results demonstrate that the EKF achieves sub-meter accuracy and robustness to measurement uncertainties, with applications in robotics, autonomous navigation, and wireless sensor networks. This study provides extensive insights into algorithm design, supported by rigorous mathematical formulations and visualizations.

title: Automated Nuclei Segmentation in PR-IHC Breast Cancer Images Using the Cellpose Deep Learning Model
authors: Hasanul Bannah, Mohammad Faizal Ahmad Fauzi, Sarina Binti Mansor, Md. Shoukhin Khan, Wan Siti Halimatul, Munirah Wan Ahmad, Md Serajun Nabi, Seow Fan Chiew, Phaik Leng Cheah, Lai Meng Looi
abstract: In digital pathology, precise nuclei segmentation in immunohistochemical-stained tissue sections is essential for clinical decision-making and subsequent quantification of biomarkers. This task is particularly important for the analysis of hormone receptors in breast cancer, where the status of the progesterone receptor (PR) plays a key role in determining the response to treatment. However, because of differences in nuclear morphology, staining intensity, and overlapping structures, nucleus segmentation in PR-IHC images is still difficult. In order to separate PR-expressing nuclei from high-resolution breast cancer histopathology images, we present an automated instance segmentation frame-work in this work that is based on the Cellpose deep learning model, supported by an entirely novel ground truth (GT) dataset produced by a hybrid pipeline. In order to create the GT, 250 high-resolution PR-IHC images with trustworthy binary nuclei masks were combined with automated segmentation (StarDist), extensive manual corrections, and multiround pathological validation. On the test set, our Cellpose-based approach consistently performs properly, achieving an average F 1 score of 0.8535, precision of 0.8882, recall of 0.8215, and IoU of 0.7445. Strong segmentation of extracted and overlapping nuclei is confirmed by visual results. This study offers a useful resource for future research in hormone receptor quantification and computational pathology, as well as the first automated segmentation benchmark for the PR-IHC dataset.

title: Entropy-Rich One-Time Password Generation Utilizing Sensors in a Hardware-Realized Chaotic Chua's Circuit
authors: Tee Hui Teo, Maoyang Xiang, Zhengyao He, Qianrui Lin, RK Suriya Varshan, Yee Kiat Lim, Jing Ting Leow, Ahmad Danish Bin Azli, Matthew Wong
abstract: This paper introduces a novel hardware-based solution for generating one-time passwords (OTPs) using a field-programmable gate array (FPGA). By leveraging real-world analog noise sources like light, temperature, and sound sensors, the system ensures a high level of entropy to seed the random number generation process in a dedicated FPGA chaotic Chua's circuit. The design of this OTP generator is capable of producing secure 5-digit OTPs ranging from 00000 to 99999. These OTPs can serve various purposes, such as wireless applications when transmitted to an ESP32 microcontroller or authentication in access control systems. By integrating these OTPs directly into access control systems, organizations can enhance their security measures significantly. This integration allows for seamless and secure authentication processes, ensuring that only authorized individuals gain access to restricted areas. The proposed approach prioritizes high randomness and resistance to prediction, essential characteristics for secure embedded systems. By incorporating multiple noise sources and utilizing FPGA technology, the OTP generator guarantees a robust level of security. Overall, the hardware-based OTP generator presented in this paper stands as a reliable and innovative solution for enhancing security in embedded systems.

title: Cooperative Mapping Method with Distributed Autonomous Mobile Robots in Unknown Environments
authors: Yuma IKEDA, Keizo MIYAHARA
abstract: This paper describes a method for collecting onsite information in unknown environments, such as the size and location of obstacles, using a decentralized mapping algorithm with multiple mobile robots. Aiming at initial response to emergency disaster situations, each one of the homogeneous autonomous distributed robots determine own exploration direction by combining data clustering techniques based on only its local map at the time. The mobile robots communicate locally, when they encounter each other in the exploring field, to share the map information to enhance the efficiency of the entire mapping system. Even if some unexplored areas remained, another shape-fitting technique will be applied to the incomplete information obtained, and it enables the system to output the most-likely environment map for the subsequent principal task, such as intended rescue mission. A series of simulations were conducted to verify the proposed cooperative mapping method, and the results of the examination demonstrated its consistency and efficiency.

title: Efficient Task Scheduling Algorithms for Decentralized Large Language Model Serving
authors: Sanjaya Kumar Panda, Sankalp Dubey, Siba Mishra
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have gained enormous popularity for processing and generating text. They are a subset of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) that require higher availability of graphical processing unit (GPU) resources for inference services. However, making GPU resources available in a centralized infrastructure is quite challenging. Therefore, recent works have focused on decentralized physical infrastructure networks (DePIN) to utilize idle GPU resources, enabling scalable LLM inference services across the decentralized network. These inference services may experience inherent latency (i.e., measured in time per output token (TPOT)) due to communication overhead or time between GPU resources responsible for generating consecutive tokens. The task scheduling algorithm is crucial in decentralized LLM inference services to minimize TPOT and maximize GPU resource utilization, particularly when GPU resources are constrained by computational capacity. This paper introduces two task scheduling algorithms, the improved greedy heuristic shortest path algorithm (IGHSPA) and the dynamic programming-based task scheduling algorithm (DPTSA), for decentralized LLM serving to achieve these objectives. Each task involves assigning a layer to a GPU resource, which IGHSPA and DPTSA accomplish using greedy heuristic and dynamic programming. Both algorithms are extensively simulated and compared with one of the recent algorithms, namely the greedy heuristic shortest path algorithm (GHSPA), in terms of TPOT and execution time (ET). Our simulation results demonstrate that DPTSA improves TPOT up to 47.50% and 35.50% and ET up to 99.95% and 35.00%, compared to GHSPA and IGHSPA.

title: Research on Multi-Source Data Fusion and Cleaning Method for Distribution Networks Based on Time-Slice Synchronization
authors: Xiao Xu, You Li, Shangdian Zhang
